title-group.article-title: On the nature of extracontinental mountain forests in North Mongolia

permissions.copyright-statement: © Department of Plant Taxonomy and Ecology, ELTE

abstract.p: Based on data from many-year investigations of mountain forests in the Khangai Upland (North Mongolia), the functioning of forest ecosystems under extreme environmental conditions (winter frosts and cryogenic soil moistening) is analyzed. We consider the physical nature of forest functioning as being determined by material and energy pathways between the community and the environment, as well as by the pattern of activity revealed by the ecosystem under actual conditions. The differences in the water regime of forest communities are discussed in a wide zonal aspect as they were observed along the longitudinal climatic gradient. It is suggested that under the conditions of extracontinental arid climate, the substantial increase of the activity and flexibility of physiological reactions in autotrophic organisms is mainly responsible for the functioning of ecosystems. As a result, energy consumption by the community accelerates and becomes more effective.
